Description: You can easily generate Villagers with Necromancer as soon as an Acting Troupe has ended up in the trash.
With Advance around, gaining Death Cart is not as detrimental as you may trash the Ruins into something useful.
As soon as Enlightenment is active, Coppers become great targets for Advance.
Minor reveal synergy to generate Coffers while drawing.
You can Change Coppers/Estates into Alchemist for just 3/1 Debt.
If you play Alchemists and buy Journey, as long as you have a Potion in play, you may topdeck the Alchemists for the Journey turn. You may again do so on the Journey turn.
If Alchemist is Reckless, you may topdeck it during Clean-up if you have a Potion in play, circumventing Reckless' return-to-pile prompt.
When under the Enchantress attack, playing Alley from your deck is essentially a Laboratory
Playing Alleys from your deck using Way of the Mule essentially turns them into flexible, reliable Peddlers (+1 Card, +1 Action, +1$) that are available whenever you shuffle.
Playing Alleys from your deck using Way of the Otter essentially turns them into flexible, reliable Smithies that are available whenever you shuffle.
Playing Alleys from your deck using Way of the Ox essentially turns them into flexible, reliable Villages that are available whenever you shuffle.
Playing Alleys from your deck using Way of the Pig essentially turns them into flexible, reliable Laboratories that are available whenever you shuffle.

After buying a bunch of Merchant Guilds and hitting $10, trying to Alliance a bunch of times (while generating Coffers) can be a viable rush, especially if there is no Alt-VP available and the kingdom is on the weaker side.
The cost reduction from Bridge Trolls will allow Alms to gain more expensive cards, and might encourage not having Treasures in play.
Almsing for Cavalry will allow you to play your Treasures after having returned to your Action phase, making for a great opening, especially with abundant Villages.
Almsing Cemetery early on can very quickly get you thin.
Almsing is a way to get around the Haunted Woods attack, which is especially relevant if there is cost reduction around.
Almsing for Hostelries will get you rolling really quickly, as you can easily add 4 Horses and a Hostelry with a $4 hand.
With virtual coin available, buying Mirror before Almsing can let you gain additional Actions for $3 each without requiring the buys.
Almsing is pretty nice on Mission turns where you wouldn't be able to buy anything anyway.
Almsing is pretty nice on otherwise unproductive Voyage turns.
Almsing is a way to get around the Swamp Hag attack, which is especially relevant if there is cost reduction around.
Almsing for Villas will allow you to play your Treasures later, allowing for an opening with $1 more, and staying relevant throughout the game.

Usually, the problem with Rebuild can be getting enough of them into your deck quickly - Amass lets you open double Rebuild, and allows you to easily pick up more if you miss them. Don't forget to buy some extra Duchies and Estates a bit later on as well! Be careful at evaluating this though, as some fast engine strategies (that also benefit from the early Amass boost) might still pose a challenge.
Apprenticing Golds while discarding Market Squares is a nice Engine in itself, providing draw, Buys, and payload.
As soon as Enlightenment is active, you'll be able to discard Coppers to Arena for some VP.
Discarding Faithful Hound to Arena will put it in hand for your next turn, where you'll be able to discard it again.
Neat little synergy to play Village Greens for next turn for free while also picking up VP.

Arena offers you to play a Weaver for free during each of your turns, initially even getting you VP for it. You can still use this even if no VP are left on Arena, just keep in mind that there might be an autoplay in the online clients preventing you.
Artificer and Cursed Village's draw-to-6 go together quite well.
Artificer might benefit from Ferry's cost reduction, including on Artificer itself.
Artificer and First Mate's draw-to-6 go together quite well.
With Artificer, you can both easily gain more Menageries and activate their draw effect via smart discards.
With Artificer, if you manage to draw deck and discard lots of Actions, you can easily redraw them using Scrying Pools, enabling powerful gain-and-play stuff.
Gaining Sheepdogs to hand allows you to immediately play them for draw.
With Mirror, you can gain additional Artists for $3 each.

Stock up on Astrolabes, buy Guildhall ASAP and then spam Astrolabes and Coppers with all the remaining buys. Can usually finish off the game with a double Province, will hit 6 Provinces after 12 to 14 turns (depending on when you hit $5).
If you gain a Siren and somehow trigger a shuffle (e.g. on t2) by drawing a card using Band of Nomads, you are no longer required to trash an Action card for the Siren to stay in your deck.
With Monkey around, Bandit Camps might draw your opponent lots of cards.
As soon as Enlightenment is active, Banquet essentially becomes a cheap way to gain more expensive cards.
Sometimes, getting a few Merchant Guilds in play and spamming Banquet to rack up Coffers is a good way to get a quick boost.
Having a Fortress trashed from the top of your deck will put it into your hand and gain you a cheaper Action card.

With Barbarian, you can trash your opponent's Overlords into Curses, while also playing Overlords as Barbarians is possible, making for a weird game of luck (I'm not even sure what to classify this as).
With Scrying Pool, you might be able to set up targets for Barbarian. On the other hand, getting your own Scrying Pool trashed is awful as you will gain a Curse for it.
Having a Trail trashed from the top of your deck will allow you to draw a card, and gain a cheaper Action card.
As long as you have $2, playing Lucky Coin will give you +2 VP from Basilica.
Buying a Hostelry with at least $6 will let you gobble up Basilica points for the Hostelry and each Horse you gain.
Gaining Marchlands in your Buy phase and discarding at least 2 cards for $ will also give you 2 Basilica VP even if you have $0 prior to gaining them.
Gaining Nomads in your Buy phase will give you $2, and thus also give you 2 Basilica VP even if you have $0 prior to gaining them.
Playing Cursed Gold and gaining a Curse will give you +2 VP from Basilica.
Hitting $7 and buying Stampede will let you gobble up Basilica points.
As long as you have $2, playing Supplies will give you +2 VP from Basilica.
Preparing a Night card such as Bat will prevent you from being able to play it during your Night phase, and at the start of your next turn, it will just be discarded.
Get +3 VP each turn you hit $4 while bring the game to an end quickly using Salt the Earth on Province. Fails if opponent can get to ~20 VP in ~10 turns while contesting some Baths points.
As soon as Enlightenment is active, Beggar basically becomes a Smithy with optional Payload.
If you have an easy way of trashing the Coppers, Beggar can work as draw, and on rare weak kingdoms, rushing Beggars can make for a weird strategy.
Hammering in Beggars and buying Guildhall ASAP is a strong 2-CSO combo, reaching ~6 Provinces by turn 12.
Once Panic is active, the Coppers gained from Beggar are returned after playing them, so essentially Beggar becomes a terminal Gold with 6 Buys attached to it.
Biding Time being active lets you easily kick off with City Quarters.
Insane start-of-turn draw if you have stashed away a few Victory cards.

Once Biding Time is active, unless there is a way to discard them, you won't be able to trash any unplayable cards (like Curses) via Donate anymore as the Donate trashing happens before the Biding Time cards are put back into your hand.
Frigate can shut down Biding Time pretty well.
Haunted Woods can shut down strategies relying on Biding Time pretty well.
Biding Time being active lets you easily kick off with Magnate, and drawing dead Village isn't as bad as you will get to play them on the next turn.

Mission is super nice once Biding Time is active, as it allows you to stash away the cards you don't use on your extra turn, essentially trading $4 and a buy for at least 5 extra cards in your next-turn hand.
Voyage is super nice once Biding Time is active, as it allows you to stash away the cards you don't use.
Biding Time can both set up Outpost turns or, if they are duds, you can at least stash away three cards for the next one. Sometimes, gaining a second Outpost to ensure always playing one is worth it.
If you don't have any way to discard green cards, they will accumulate in your hand, and you won't be able to Rebuild them once Biding Time is active.
Reacting Sheepdogs in your Buy phase once Biding Time is active will draw you cards that you can set aside for your next turn.
Very nice to set up lots of Shepherd draw. Might very well be worth not trashing any Estates, especially if Biding Time is likely to activate quickly.
Since you discard your whole hand with Tactician, you won't be able to benefit from Biding Time on that turn, making Tactician decks less viable.
Having three Tea Houses and a Silver quickly becomes a golden Deck that can Province each turn, even immune to most discard attacks. Can sometimes be a bit clunky to set up.
Reacting Trails in your Buy phase once Biding Time is active will draw you cards that you can set aside for your next turn.
Due to the timing of Guardian, you will not be protected from your opponent Cursing you with Black Cats during your turn.
With a Lighthouse played this turn (!), you can avoid being Cursed by your opponent's Black Cats when greening. They'll still draw the cards for free though.
With a Moat in hand, you can avoid being Cursed by your opponent's Black Cats when greening. They'll still draw the cards for free though.
The presence of Black Cats should disincentivize going for a Rebuild strategy, as you would inevitably gain green cards.
With a Watchtower in hand, you can avoid being Cursed by your opponent's Black Cats when greening. They'll still draw the cards for free though.
With Capitalism active, you can chain Black Markets.
Playing Gatekeeper before your opponent plays Black Market will lock them out of gaining most cards from Black Market.
Haunted Woods can shut down Black Market, as you are forced to topdeck your hand when buying cards from the Black Market when under the Haunted Woods attack.
Keep heavily incentivizes going for Treasures from the Black Market deck, as each will give you uncontested 5 VP.
Each unique card from the Black Market will be worth an additional 2 VP with Museum around.
Playing Black Market before Tactician allows you to get your Treasures into play before discarding your hand.
With Capitalism active, you can play Bridges nonterminally, which quickly scales up.
Monolithically just getting 6 Flagships and a Bridge in play will enable you to pile Provinces in ~12 turns if uncontested.
With lots of draw, it might be worth gunning for just having 4 Bridges and $6 in hand. Just make sure you extra Buys and you can easily pile Provinces
Playing Bridges as Way of the Turtle can lead to a megaturn, but might take a while to set up, so usually some support is needed.
Racking up 10 Favors can make Brokers pretty strong, providing Actions, Buys, and flexibility when trashing stuff.
Horse gainers such as Cavalry are much worse with Bureaucracy active, as each Horse gain comes with a Copper (bar cost reduction active).
Horse gainers such as Demand are much worse with Bureaucracy active, as each Horse gain comes with a Copper (bar cost reduction active).
Horse gainers such as Groom are much worse with Bureaucracy active, as each Horse gain comes with a Copper (bar cost reduction active).
Horse gainers such as Hostelry are much worse with Bureaucracy active, as each Horse gain comes with a Copper (bar cost reduction active).
Horse gainers such as Livery are much worse with Bureaucracy active, as each Horse gain comes with a Copper (bar cost reduction active).
Horse gainers such as Paddock are much worse with Bureaucracy active, as each Horse gain comes with a Copper (bar cost reduction active).
You don't gain Coppers off of buying Peddlers that have been reduced to 0.
With Quarries reducing the cost of Action cards to 0, you can circumvent having to gain Coppers when buying them.
Horse gainers such as Scrap are much worse with Bureaucracy active, as each Horse gain comes with a Copper (bar cost reduction active).
Horse gainers such as Sleigh are much worse with Bureaucracy active, as each Horse gain comes with a Copper (bar cost reduction active).
Horse gainers such as Stampede are much worse with Bureaucracy active, as each Horse gain comes with a Copper (bar cost reduction active).
Horse gainers such as Supplies are much worse with Bureaucracy active, as each Horse gain comes with a Copper (bar cost reduction active).

Playing Cabin Boys becomes very attractive with Shaman around, as you can trash it at the start of your turn to gain another Cabin Boy or stronger Duration, and immediately regain it from the trash (also circumventing having to gain a junk card). Having at least a pair of them is recommended.
As long as you stash away your Capitals in Crypts, you never have to take the 6D.
Even if you topdeck a Capital via Herbalist, you still have to take the debt.
Even if the on-play effect of Capital is nullified by an opponent's Highwayman attack, you will still need to take 6D upon discarding it from play.
Even if you set aside the Capital via Trickster, you still have to take the debt.
As soon as Enlightenment is active, Capitalism can turn your juicy $-bearing Actions into Cantrips during the Action phase.
Great way to topdeck the Landing Parties each turn if there is a +$-giving cantrip.
As soon as Panic is active, Capitalism will cause you to return your $-bearing Actions to the Supply when discarding them from play.
With Capitalism bought, playing Patrons as Treasures will turn them into Villages.
With Capitalism active, you can play the Souks as the last Treasures, increasing their value.
With Footpad around, Carpenter becomes super strong, and with an empty deck and discard pile, Carpenter can autopile as long as on other piles are empty.
With Keep around, Humble Castle will be worth 5 extra VP, sometimes even making it worth opening.
Castles are worth an extra 2 VP with Museum around.
Getting Collections in play before returning to your Action phase and gaining more cards (such as Horses from Cavalry plays) is a good way to rack up VP quickly.
Horses are great targets for Conclave as they will leave play.
Since Harsh Winter puts debt on any pile (including Horses), gaining a bunch of Horses with Cavalry is usually pretty punishing.
You get to play Treasures to topdeck the Landing Parties, and can then Buy Cavalry to return to your Action phase and even draw two of them immediately.
With Monkey around, gaining Horses with Cavalry will usually be much less attractive.
Horses are insane Procession targets. Whatever you do, using Cavalry to stuff Horses and Processions into the deck as soon as possible is usually a winning move.
Having two Quarries in play lets you autopile Cavalries while drawing a bunch of cards.
Gaining Cavalries with Quartermaster will start off your turn with +2 Cards, +1 Buy.
Very convenient to gain/buy a few things and return to your Action phase (gaining Horses helps, but also if you manage to gain three cards without having to play Cavalry)
Once you've drawn your deck, buying a Stockpile while discarding the others from Exile and then Cavalries can often lead to loopy situations, as you get to reuse the same Stockpiles multiple times.

Night cards such as Ghost gained from trashing Haunted Mirror are heavily disincentivized with Haunted Woods around, as you will have to topdeck your hand whenever buying cards, which happens before you would be able to play any Night cards.
With Treasurer, you can regain Haunted Mirrors from the trash in order to gain multiple Ghosts.
You can Change Coppers/Estates into Familiars for just 3/1 Debt.
You can Change Coppers/Estates into Fortune for just 8/6 Debt.
You can Change Coppers and Estates into Golems for just 4/2 Debt.
You can Change Coppers/Estates into Philosopher's Stones for just 3/1 Debt. Whether you really want that is another question.
You can Change Coppers/Estates into Possession for just 6/4 Debt.
You can Change Coppers into Scrying Pools for just 2 Debt.
You can Change Coppers into Universities for just 2 Debt.
Night cards are heavily disincentivized with Haunted Woods around, as you will have to topdeck your hand whenever buying cards, which happens before you would be able to play any Night cards.
Preparing a Night card such as Changeling will prevent you from being able to play it during your Night phase, and at the start of your next turn, it will just be discarded.
Don't miss out on the Travelling Fair/Chapel opening, especially powerful on the 4/3 or 5/2 as you'll get to trash before shuffling.
With Forum, you can sometimes neatly set up the targets for Chariot Race.
Once Enlightenment is active, you get to cantrip Curses and they become an Action-Treasure-Curse card, which also might have its merits.
Once Panic is active, you get to return Curses to their pile by playing them.
In games where it's likely that players are going for Cursing, Pirate is more likely to be activated regularly.
Allows for nice start-of-turn Crossroads draw if you manage to set aside two Estates and a Crossroads each turn.
Strong synergy, especially with gainers. It allows to play each Action on gain if you manage to get two Guildmasters played.
If you gain a Siren and use City-State to play the Siren, Siren no longer requires you to trash an Action card from your hand in order to not trash the Siren.
City Gate provides reliable setup for Piazza hitting the cards you want.
As soon as Enlightenment is active, City Quarter can draw cards more easily.
With Mirror, you can gain additional City Quarters for $3 each.
Revealing your hand with a few Patrons in it generates Coffers while drawing you cards.
Getting hit by Clerk's attack provides reliable setup for Piazza hitting an Action card.
Night cards are heavily disincentivized with Haunted Woods around, as you will have to topdeck your hand whenever buying cards, which happens before you would be able to play any Night cards.
Preparing a Night card such as Cobbler will prevent you from being able to play it during your Night phase, and at the start of your next turn, it will just be discarded.
Cobblers are great flexible start-of-turn gainers that allow you to pick up Shepherds or Estates as needed to kick off your turns.
As soon as Enlightenment is active, it becomes even more attractive to get more Collections, as all Treasures will also be Actions.
Securing at least 5 Collections should be a priority, as you can indefinitely rack up 50 VP/turn by just playing those, and double Stampeding.
Playing Collections before Supplies will give you VP tokens for each Horse gain.
As soon as Enlightenment is active, buying Coppers can yield Colonnade points.
Horses are great targets for Conclave as they will leave play.
Horses are great targets for Conclave as they will leave play.
Horses are great targets for Conclave as they will leave play.
Horses are great targets for Conclave as they will leave play.
Horses are great targets for Conclave as they will leave play.
Horses are great targets for Conclave as they will leave play.
Horses are great targets for Conclave as they will leave play.
Horses are great targets for Conclave as they will leave play.
Horses are great targets for Conclave as they will leave play.
With Way of the Chameleon, Conclaves become flexible Lost City-variants as long as you have diverse decks.
Continuing for Hermit lets you gain Madman rather easily, as you exchange Hermits after *any* buy phase; if you don't buy any cards in your last one, you are set.
You get to play Treasures to topdeck the Landing Parties, and can then Continue.
Good way to get loads of Golds into your deck quickly.
Minor reveal synergy to generate Coffers while revealing Patron to Courtier, and Patron is also a dual-type card.
Crafter's Guild provides reliable setup to immediately play Action cards you gain onto the top of your deck.
Crew topdecking itself at the start of your turn provides reliable setup for Piazza, letting you start with three extra cards in hand reliably.
Revealing your hand with a few Patrons in it generates Coffers.
If Crossroads is Reckless, the first time you play one will give you +6 Actions.
Crowns will become cantrips during the Action phase.
If Crown is the only Village, then Highwayman is really effective in shutting that down.
Great way to topdeck the Landing Parties each turn.
You can Turtle a Crown in your Buy phase without needing to spend an Action to play it at the start of another turn.
Night cards are heavily disincentivized with Haunted Woods around, as you will have to topdeck your hand whenever buying cards, which happens before you would be able to play any Night cards.
Stashing away Treasures in Crypts will prevent them from being affected by Panic, yielding lots of buys.
Preparing a Night card such as Crypt will prevent you from being able to play it during your Night phase, and at the start of your next turn, it will just be discarded.
Ruins with their dual type are great targets for Maroon. Thus, you might want to reconsider getting Cultists in the kingdom.
With Way of the Horse, playing Cultist will provide your opponent with free Horses. Not advised.
With Way of the Pig, playing Cultist to give your opponent Ruins will not do as much damage as your opponent can always pig them.
Playing Gatekeeper before your opponent gains Loot via Cursed will usually prevent them from getting the Loot into their deck.
Keep heavily incentivizes going for Loot, as each unique one will represent at least 5 VP over your opponent.

Pulling Sword from the Loot pile might be especially impactful in games where you would gain lots of cards during your Action phase. On the other hand, pulling Shield is also great as you might be more likely to have it in hand when attacked.
Any unique Loot you manage to pull will be worth 2 VP at the end of the game.

Once Panic is active, Loots will return to the top of their pile (so the next Loot gain will pick them up) when discarded from play, so unless you pull Endless Chalice, Spell Scroll or Jewels, they are usually not worth going for if Panic is likely to activate.
If you pull Insignia from the Loots pile, you can use it to topdeck Sirens without the need for trashing an Action.
Pulling Spell Scroll from the Loots can autopile Treasurers.
With Watchtower in hand, you can immediately trash the Curse (and even the Cursed card) when gaining a Cursed card, and even topdeck the Loot if you so want it.
Making your opponent reveal a hand of Patrons might not have the desired effect. In games with Cutpurse, Patron and Copper trashing, this might disincentivize going for Cutpurse even more.
Playing Gatekeeper before your opponent gains Loot via Cutthroat will usually prevent them from getting the Loot into their deck.
Keep heavily incentivizes going for Loot, as each unique one will represent at least 5 VP over your opponent.

Pulling Sword from the Loot pile might be especially impactful in games where you would gain lots of cards during your Action phase. On the other hand, pulling Shield is also great as you might be more likely to have it in hand when attacked.
Any unique Loot you manage to pull will be worth 2 VP at the end of the game.

Once Panic is active, Loots will return to the top of their pile (so the next Loot gain will pick them up) when discarded from play, so unless you pull Endless Chalice, Spell Scroll or Jewels, they are usually not worth going for if Panic is likely to activate.
If you pull Insignia from the Loots pile, you can use it to topdeck Sirens without the need for trashing an Action.
Pulling Spell Scroll from the Loots can autopile Treasurers.
As soon as Enlightenment is active, playing a Daimyo before ending your Action phase will let you double-play Treasures for their Treasure effect.
Being able to combine Renown with a couple of Daimyos is usually game-winning
Very loopy replays of King's Court are possible here.
With Mirror, you can gain additional Daimyos for $3 each.
Playing Daimyo/Disciple/Daimyo with an otherwise empty deck will autopile Daimyos and let you gain a bunch of other stuff.
With Museum around, gaining Death Cart at the end of the game can provide some important extra VP.
With Way of the Horse, by gaining Death Cart you essentially add three flexible Horses to your deck.
With Way of the Pig, gaining the Ruins from Death Cart is not as detrimental as you can always pig them.
With Woodworkers' Guild around, gaining Death Cart is not as detrimental as you may trash the Ruins into something useful.

You really want to be the one triggering the Prophecy. Especially look out for it with Mountain Shrine, which you can in principle Deliver t1; but also with the other Omens, once it kicks in, you're in for a Copper flood ride. Watch out for Handsize attacks though!
On 5/2 or 4/3 openings, you may be able to junk the opponent as player 1 before they shuffle.
You can Deliver Sirens for $5 without the need to trash an Action for the Siren gain - quite strong (bit swingy in the opening)

On weak boards, spamming Delve a lot, followed up by grabbing 6 or more VP-Feoda might be the way to go. Wouldn't recommend against medium-strong engines though as you will lack a lot of agency, especially if they can somehow contest the Feoda. But you can reach a staggering amount of points by t17 or so.

Spam Delve until you can't, buy Guildhall ASAP, and spam more Delves, flooding the deck with Silver. Once Guildhall is acquired, finish off the Delve chain with a Copper buy. Having $1 can be spent on a Delve buy without losing Coffers. Start Provincing with a stash of Coppers, you should hit 6 Provinces by t13.
Since Harsh Winter puts debt on any pile (including Horses), gaining a bunch of Horses with Demand is usually pretty punishing.
With Monkey around, gaining Horses with Demand will usually be much less attractive.
Horses are insane Procession targets. Whatever you do, using Demand to stuff Horses and Processions into the deck as soon as possible is usually a winning move.

Night cards are heavily disincentivized with Haunted Woods around, as you will have to topdeck your hand whenever buying cards, which happens before you would be able to play any Night cards. When buying Den of Sin while under the HW attack, it even topdecked immediately instead of gained to your hand.
Preparing a Night card such as Den of Sin will prevent you from being able to play it during your Night phase, and at the start of your next turn, it will just be discarded.
With Watchtower in hand, you can trash the Curses you gain from buying Desperation, essentially making it worth $2 and giving you the ability to topdeck stuff.
With a $5 cost draw card, there is an autopile with KC/KC/Develop as long as there's a $4 cost available, piling lots of things.
Developing Coppers or Estates will gain you Poor Houses, which you usually don't want.
Night cards are heavily disincentivized with Haunted Woods around, as you will have to topdeck your hand whenever buying cards, which happens before you would be able to play any Night cards.
Preparing a Night card such as Devil's Workshop will prevent you from being able to play it during your Night phase, and at the start of your next turn, it will just be discarded.
With a $5 cost draw card, there is an autopile with KC/KC/Displace by Displacing King's Courts into the draw cards and Displaces, and the Draw card into KCs.
Innovation makes Distant Land gains stronger - essentially 4 VP chips for $5 and passing up on your Innovation otherwise.
All cards of the initial kingdom lose access to their piles, so they become optional Labs once the Prophecy activates.
Great to get lots of payload and buys into deck quickly.
When under the Enchantress attack, playing Fishmonger from your deck is essentially a Laboratory
When under the Enchantress attack, playing Ninja from your deck is essentially a Laboratory
When under the Enchantress attack, playing Ronin from your deck is essentially a Laboratory
When under the Enchantress attack, playing Tanuki from your deck is essentially a Laboratory
With Shaman around, you can trash a valuable card at the start of your turn with Enlarge, regaining it immediately (also circumventing having to gain a junk card).
As soon as Enlightenment is active, Falconer can be activated by any Treasure gain.
With Enlightenment active, Scribes might allow you to draw in during your buy phase.
As soon as Enlightenment is active, playing a Flagship before ending your Action phase will let you double-play Treasures for their Treasure effect.
As soon as Enlightenment is active, you can Cantrip the first FG and then play further ones for +$4 during your Buy phase.
As soon as Enlightenment is active, Graverobber will be able to Trash and retrieve Treasures - turn those Golds into Provinces.

With Enlightenment active, when playing a Treasure during your Action phase while under Highwayman attack, you get to choose which effect applies first, so you can still get +1 Card, +1 Action and Highwayman's attack essentially does not have any effect.
As soon as Enlightenment is active, the double-types will help Hunter draw as you'll be able to choose the type to draw them for.
Great way to topdeck the Landing Parties each turn and draw into them easily as soon as Enlightenment is active.
As soon as Enlightenment is active, Magpies will usually breed super quickly, so it pays off to be the one triggering.
As soon as Enlightenment is active, Coppers in the trash will be Actions and Mountain Shrine will draw you cards.
As soon as Enlightenment has been activated, Orchard will consider triplets of Action-Treasures for scoring.
As soon as Enlightenment is active, Coppers are easy Peril targets.
Once Enlightenment is active, you can Practice Treasures (which might be useful with kingdom Treasures).
As soon as Enlightenment is active, non-Duration Treasures will be viable Procession targets, and you can also Process $5s into Golds.
As soon as Enlightenment is active, Quarries will also reduce the cost of formerly Treasures-only.
As soon as Enlightenment is active, Trashing Coppers to Rice Broker will draw you 7 cards!
Coppers become pretty neat Sacrifice targets once Enlightenment is active.
As soon as Enlightenment is active, Scrying Pool draw becomes supercharged
As soon as Enlightenment is active, Sea Trade will benefit from all of these Action-Treasures in play. You might not need the thinning at that point anymore, but sometimes this might be relevant.
As soon as Enlightenment is active, Shanty Town will be even harder to activate (although you can of course Cantrip away your Treasures).
As soon as Enlightenment is active, Coppers are easy targets to trash while gaining Sirens.
Storyteller becomes a Village with Enlightenment active, but its draw capabilities will be limited.
As soon as Enlightenment is active, Treasures can be swapped around easily. Especially great for Coppers.
Treasures will count as Actions for scoring purposes, making keeping Coppers attractive if the Prophecy is likely to unfold.
As soon as Enlightenment has been activated, Vineyards will count Treasures towards their VP for scoring.
As soon as Enlightenment is active, Treasures can also be Butterfly'd, even non-terminally during your buy phase.
If you play your Treasures using Chameleon during your Buy phase, you will draw cards for any +$ (and vice versa). During your Action phase, even Chameleoning Actions will give +1 Card, +1 Action.
As soon as Enlightenment is active, Way of the Horse will turn all of your Treasures into Horses, making for explosive draw (even in the Buy phase, if desired).
As soon as Enlightenment is active, Way of the Monkey will allow you to play any Treasure as +$1, +1 Buy during your buy phase.
As soon as Enlightenment is active, Way of the Sheep will allow you to play any Treasure as Silvers during your buy phase.
As soon as Enlightenment is active, Way of the Squirrel will allow you to play any Treasure as Squirrels during your buy phase for lots of next-turn handsize increases.
As soon as Enlightenment is active, Way of the Turtle will allow you to play any Treasure as Turtles during your buy phase for lots of next-turn Village effects.
As soon as Enlightenment is active, Coppers become great targets for Woodworkers Guild.
Minor reveal synergy to generate Coffers while drawing. The Villagers also come in pretty handy with Envoys.
Night cards are heavily disincentivized with Haunted Woods around, as you will have to topdeck your hand whenever buying cards, which happens before you would be able to play any Night cards.
Preparing a Night card such as Exorcist will prevent you from being able to play it during your Night phase, and at the start of your next turn, it will just be discarded.
Gaining Sheepdogs to hand allows you to immediately play them for draw, and also helps to trigger other Falconers you (or your opponent) might have in hand.
With Woodworkers' Guild, you can trash an Action card into a Possession without having to gain a Potion.
Reducing the cost of Farrier to 0 with Ferry allows to overpay super easily.
If Patron is Fated, you get to reveal Patrons whenever you shuffle your deck, so if you manage to do so during your Action phase, you will generate Coffers.
Trashing Coppers with Student and redrawing it with Scribes can get you thin really quickly.
Get Silvers in deck quickly if needed.
With Watchtower in hand, you can immediately trash any Feoda you gain, which is sometimes nice to give you a boost in payload.

Usually, the problem with Rebuild can be getting enough of them into your deck quickly - if you manage to put Ferry on Rebuild t1, throwing loads of Rebuilds into the deck and hoping for the best can empty Provinces with ~18 points by t11. Just be aware that strong engines also might be sped up by Ferry being around.
Reducing the cost of Stonemason to 0 with Ferry allows to overpay for Actions easily.
With Way of the Chameleon, Festivals become flexible Lost City-variants with +Buy slapped on.
With an empty discard pile, you may gobble up lots of Fishermen for $2 using the TFair topdecking
Playing Fishmongers from your deck using Way of the Mule essentially turns them into flexible, reliable Peddlers (+1 Card, +1 Action, +1$) that are available whenever you shuffle.
Playing Fishmongers from your deck using Way of the Otter essentially turns them into flexible, reliable Smithies that are available whenever you shuffle.
Playing Fishmongers from your deck using Way of the Ox essentially turns them into flexible, reliable Villages that are available whenever you shuffle.
Playing Fishmongers from your deck using Way of the Pig essentially turns them into flexible, reliable Laboratories that are available whenever you shuffle.
With Footpad around, Ironworks becomes super strong, and with an empty deck and discard pile, Ironworks autopiles, easily threatening pileouts.
Gaining Magpies just became even more attractive.
Fortune Hunter can sometimes draw you an insane amount of cards
With Footpad around, Quartermaster is supercharged.
Junking your opponent might not be as desirable with Footpad around, as they'll draw extra cards for it, but of course it still might be the best thing to do.
With Footpad around, Swap becomes a Laboratory that offers loads of flexibility.
You draw the Golds immediately.
Playing Gatekeeper before your opponent gains Loot via Foray will usually prevent them from getting the Loot into their deck.
Keep heavily incentivizes going for Loot, as each unique one will represent at least 5 VP over your opponent.

Pulling Sword from the Loot pile might be especially impactful in games where you would gain lots of cards during your Action phase. On the other hand, pulling Shield is also great as you might be more likely to have it in hand when attacked.
Any unique Loot you manage to pull will be worth 2 VP at the end of the game.

Once Panic is active, Loots will return to the top of their pile (so the next Loot gain will pick them up) when discarded from play, so unless you pull Endless Chalice, Spell Scroll or Jewels, they are usually not worth going for if Panic is likely to activate.
If you pull Insignia from the Loots pile, you can use it to topdeck Sirens without the need for trashing an Action.
Pulling Spell Scroll from the Loots can autopile Treasurers.
Forest Dwellers provide semi-reliable setup for Piazza hitting the card you want.
Having a Fortress trashed from the top of your deck will put it into your hand.
Having a Fortress trashed from the top of your deck will put it into your hand.
Trashing Fortresses from the Supply with Lurker will gain them to your hand.
Having a Fortress trashed from the top of your deck will put it into your hand.
Having a Fortress trashed from the top of your deck will put it into your hand and gain you another $4-cost card.
Having a Fortress trashed from the top of your deck via Warrior will put it into your hand.
If Forts are Reckless, you may topdeck Tent during Clean-up, essentially making it a self-topdecking Terminal +$4.
With two or three Quarries, you can threaten to immediately pile Fora pretty easily.
Forum discards, Trail activates on discard, effectively turning Forum into a drawing Village.
Forum discards, VG activates on discard, effectively turning Forum into a drawing Village.

What at first sounds like a nombo as you'll probably get rid of your Coppers early on with Panic active, the extra buys from Panic can threaten to finish the game with buying 10 Coppers for a nice Boost in VP.

Can quickly generate a lot of money. The goal is to have an empty hand during your buy phase and Gamble into a bunch of Souks, which will autopile at that point. One should focus on trashing out the Estates; opening double Silver should be a good way to get going.
Buying Stockpiles with an empty deck and discard pile and Gambling back into them can generate a lot of money.
A rush out of the books - stock up on Grooms, then nail the Gardens, and finish up on Estates.
Playing Gatekeeper before your opponent gains Loot via Invasion will usually prevent them from getting the Loot into their deck.
Playing Gatekeeper before your opponent gains Loot via Jewelled Egg will usually prevent them from getting the Loot into their deck.
Playing Gatekeeper before your opponent gains Loot via Looting will usually prevent them from getting the Loot into their deck.
Playing Gatekeeper before your opponent gains Loot via Peril will usually prevent them from getting the Loot into their deck.
Playing Gatekeeper before your opponent gains Loot via Pickaxe will usually prevent them from getting the Loot into their deck.
Playing Gatekeeper before your opponent gains Loot via Prosper will usually prevent them from getting the Loot into their deck.
Playing Gatekeeper before your opponent gains Loot via Sack of Loot will usually prevent them from getting the Loot into their deck.
Playing Gatekeeper before your opponent gains Loot via Search will usually prevent them from getting the Loot into their deck.
Playing Gatekeeper before your opponent gains Loot via Wealthy Village will usually prevent them from getting the Loot into their deck.
Preparing a Night card such as Ghost will prevent you from being able to play it during your Night phase, and at the start of your next turn, it will just be discarded.

Night cards are heavily disincentivized with Haunted Woods around, as you will have to topdeck your hand whenever buying cards, which happens before you would be able to play any Night cards. When buying Ghost Town while under the HW attack, it even topdecked immediately instead of gained to your hand.
Preparing a Night card such as Ghost Town will prevent you from being able to play it during your Night phase, and at the start of your next turn, it will just be discarded.
Having a Trail trashed from the top of your deck will allow you to draw a card.
With Woodworkers' Guild, you can trash an Action card into a Possession without having to gain a Potion.
Playing two Quarries allows you to buy Grand Markets, and having Grand Markets in combination with Quarries allows to pile out quickly.
Playing Vault and discarding your hand allows to buy Grand Market even with lots of Coppers in deck.
Since Harsh Winter puts debt on any pile (including Horses), gaining a bunch of Horses with Groom is usually pretty punishing.
Just as with Gardens, going for Grooms and then Islands is a strong rush strategy. You even get Horses on Island gains, what more do you want?
Just as with Gardens, going for Grooms and then Mills is a strong rush strategy. You even get Horses on Mill gains, what more do you want?
With Monkey around, gaining Horses with Groom will usually be much less attractive.
Horses are insane Procession targets. Whatever you do, using Groom to stuff Horses and Processions into the deck as soon as possible is usually a winning move.
As soon as you gain the first Loot from Wealthy Village with Growth active, you will be able to gain all remaining Wealthy Villages, as well as (if desired) some Golds along the way.

Getting Guardian in deck before your opponent plays their first Haunted Woods might be crucial as when buying Guardian while under the HW attack, it even topdecked immediately instead of gained to your hand. Night cards are heavily disincentivized with Haunted Woods around, as you will have to topdeck your hand whenever buying cards, which happens before you would be able to play any Night cards.
Preparing a Night card such as Guardian will prevent you from being able to play it during your Night phase, and at the start of your next turn, it will just be discarded.
Guides are a great way to start the Outpost turn with a full hand.
You can easily buy a load of Coppers to get a load of Coffers with Panic active.
In Shaman games, you might gain a lot of Coppers at the start of your turn, increasing the value of Guildhall a bit.
On weak boards, a variation of Guildhall/Spices/Money might be the best strategy.
On weak boards, a variation of Guildhall/Treasure Trove/Money might be the best strategy.
Since Harsh Winter puts debt on any pile (including Horses), gaining a bunch of Horses with Hostelry is usually pretty punishing.
Since Harsh Winter puts debt on any pile (including Horses), gaining a bunch of Horses with Livery is usually pretty punishing.
Since Harsh Winter puts debt on any pile (including Horses), gaining a bunch of Horses with Paddock is usually pretty punishing.
Since Harsh Winter puts debt on any pile (including Horses), gaining a bunch of Horses with Scrap is usually pretty punishing.
Since Harsh Winter puts debt on any pile (including Horses), gaining a bunch of Horses with Sleigh is usually pretty punishing.
Since Harsh Winter puts debt on any pile (including Horses), gaining a bunch of Horses with Stampede is usually pretty punishing.
Since Harsh Winter puts debt on any pile (including Horses), gaining a bunch of Horses with Supplies is usually pretty punishing.
(Only if Hasty is on a Treasure) - By buying a Hasty Treasure, you can ensure that you topdeck Landing Parties at the beginning of the next turn. Sometimes worth going out of your way for.
If you gain a Siren and set it aside using Hasty, since it's set aside after being gained, it will stay there even if you fail to trash an Action.
Night cards are heavily disincentivized with Haunted Woods around, as you will have to topdeck your hand whenever buying cards, which happens before you would be able to play any Night cards.

Night cards are heavily disincentivized with Haunted Woods around, as you will have to topdeck your hand whenever buying cards, which happens before you would be able to play any Night cards. When buying Night Watchman while under the HW attack, it even topdecked immediately instead of gained to your hand.
Night cards are heavily disincentivized with Haunted Woods around, as you will have to topdeck your hand whenever buying cards, which happens before you would be able to play any Night cards.
Night cards are heavily disincentivized with Haunted Woods around, as you will have to topdeck your hand whenever buying cards, which happens before you would be able to play any Night cards.
With SP, you can set up reliable Herald reveals.
With Herbalist, you may save Treasures from Panic. This can be relevant with kingdom Treasures or Loot you might want to keep in deck.
Used to be even more potent, but building for a megaturn after stashing a bunch of Gold, Market Squares and Madmen into your deck is still a viable strategy.
With Monkey around, gaining Horses with Hostelry will usually be much less attractive.
Horses are insane Procession targets. Whatever you do, using Hostelry to stuff Horses and Processions into the deck as soon as possible is usually a winning move.
Minor reveal synergy - revealing Patrons from your deck generates Coffers, and when revealing multiple, you can even discard them and reveal them again.
Stock up on Lurkers, just trash Hunting Grounds for Duchies and later Estates, pile out with a points lead before your opponent's deck comes together (given that they don't go for the combo)
Revealing Patrons from your deck or from your hand generates Coffers.
Improving Trail will not let you play the Trail since it is happening during the Clean-up phase.
When overpaying for and playing Infirmary, you can play it as Way of the Monkey, essentially generating the amount you manage to overpay as extra buys for $3, giving you back the money.
When overpaying for and playing Infirmary, you can play it as Way of the Sheep, essentially generating N-3 money for N $ spent - with extra buys, this can scale up quickly.
When overpaying for and playing Infirmary, you can play it as Way of the Squirrel, functioning as a $3-cost Farrier with doubled overpay benefits.
Once you have Innovation, sometimes going for Province before Joust becomes viable.
If you gain a Siren and use Innovation to play the Siren, Siren no longer requires you to trash an Action card from your hand in order to not trash the Siren.
Being able to play your first Tacticians after having played Treasures is strong.
Keep heavily incentivizes going for Loot, as each unique one will represent at least 5 VP over your opponent.

Pulling Sword from the Loot pile might be especially impactful in games where you would gain lots of cards during your Action phase. On the other hand, pulling Shield is also great as you might be more likely to have it in hand when attacked.
Any unique Loot you manage to pull will be worth 2 VP at the end of the game.

If you pull Insignia from the Loots pile, you can use it to topdeck Sirens without the need for trashing an Action.
Pulling Spell Scroll from the Loots can autopile Treasurers.
Gaining Islands with Ironworks is a great way to cantrip your Ironworks while gaining Islands, although you maybe shouldn't prioritize this.
Gaining Mills with Ironworks is a great way to cantrip your Ironworks while gaining Mills.
With a $5 cost draw card, there is an autopile you can set up by Procession/Procession/Ironworks/draw card.
Islands are sometimes good Procession targets as you will be able to set aside two cards plus the Island, and gain a $5 Action when Processing them.
Keep heavily incentivizes going for Loot, as each unique one will represent at least 5 VP over your opponent.

Pulling Spell Scroll from the Loots can autopile Treasurers.
With Watchtower in hand, you can immediately trash any Jewelled Eggs you gain and even topdeck the Loot if you so want it.
Swamp Shacks benefits from having lots of cards in play.
If you play Trickster on a turn before buying Journey, you won't be able to set aside Treasures as you wouldn't discard them from play.
Once Panic is active, both Coronet and Huge Turnip need to be returned to the Rewards pile after being played.
Keep heavily incentivizes going for Loot, as each unique one will represent at least 5 VP over your opponent.
Once Panic is active, thinking about which Treasures to keep in your deck for points leads is crucial. The extra buys might also allow you to go for some extra Coppers on your last turn.
Keep heavily incentivizes going for Loot, as each unique one will represent at least 5 VP over your opponent.

Even if no pile empties during the game, having a few Searches in play at the end (when the last Province is bought) can be game-deciding. Keep heavily incentivizes going for Loot, as each unique one will represent at least 5 VP over your opponent.
Keep heavily incentivizes going for Loot, as each unique one will represent at least 5 VP over your opponent.

Pairing two KCs with a draw card (at least Moat-like) and two Treasures in hand while having an empty deck/discard will allow you to pile out KCs and the draw card by KC/KC, Rat the first KC play, KC the draw card, ratting its first play and then drawing those four cards, and then repeating that.
Having a Trail trashed from the top of your deck will allow you to draw a card.
You get to play Treasures to topdeck the Landing Parties, and can then Launch.
(Only if Patient is on a Treasure) - By setting aside a Patient Treasure, you can ensure that you topdeck Landing Parties at the beginning of the next turn.
By buying Reap, you can ensure that you topdeck Landing Parties at the beginning of the next turn.
You get to play Treasures to topdeck the Landing Parties, and can then buy Villa to return to your Action phase and possibly play them.
Launch can help you set up the 7-card-requirement for Leprechaun by putting a few Treasures in play. Also, with Launch, the first Gold you play essentially becomes a Cantrip.
Underlings can quickly rack up Favors, becoming a cantrip after just 5 plays, and a Market-Village after 10 plays.
Playing Sheepdog by reacting to the Gold gain can sometimes help hit the 7 card requirement (but also mess it up, so be careful and only react the other ones to the wish gain).
With Monkey around, gaining Horses with Livery will usually be much less attractive.
Horses are insane Procession targets. Whatever you do, using Livery to stuff Horses and Processions into the deck as soon as possible is usually a winning move.
With SP, you can set up reliable Lookout trashes.

Pulling Sword from the Loot pile might be especially impactful in games where you would gain lots of cards during your Action phase. On the other hand, pulling Shield is also great as you might be more likely to have it in hand when attacked.

If you pull Insignia from the Loots pile, you can use it to topdeck Sirens without the need for trashing an Action.
Pulling Spell Scroll from the Loots can autopile Treasurers.
Lurker allows you to put Actions into the trash (and remove them), enabling to activate or deactivate MS's draw effect
You can add or remove targets for Necromancer from the trash using Lurker, even denying your opponent of the use of certain Zombies.
Allows to play Lurker as a Village while stuffing a Trail into your deck; especially nice if you can benefit from the trails otherwise.
Minor synergy, as playing Magnate with Patrons in hand can potentially yield a bunch of Coffers, but on the other hand won't draw you any cards.

With one or two Quartermasters in play, you can gain an Estate at the start of your turn to kick off your Mapmakers, and even put other ones into your hand first. Just make sure you don't react too many on your opponents turn to cause Mapmakerless shuffles.
Ruins are great targets for Maroon. Thus, you might want to reconsider getting any Marauder.
With Way of the Horse, playing Marauder will provide your opponent with free Horses. Not advised.
With Way of the Pig, playing Marauder to give your opponent Ruins will not do as much damage as your opponent can always pig them.
March incentivizes going for Rebuild a bit more than usual, as the ability to play it from your discard pile can accelerate the depletion of the Province pile.

Can be a deck by itself, although it requires some setup and good shuffle management. Idea is to have a few Marquis, play one, and replay it in your Buy phase using Scepter. By discarding the others and steering shuffle triggers, one can topdeck others. Is susceptible to discard attacks.
With Possession, when playing Masquerade from your opponent's perspective, you can decide which card they pass you, so sometimes it's best to not have Masq in your own deck.
Revealing your hand with a Patron in it generates Coffers. If you happen to have multiple Patrons in an otherwise unique hand, you can easily choose to play all but one to activate Menagerie draw.
If Merchant Camp is Reckless, you may topdeck it during Clean-up, essentially making it a self-topdecking +4 Actions, +$2.
You can easily buy a load of Coppers to get a load of Coffers with Panic active.
Since Supplies gains you Horses in your buy phase, playing Merchant Guild before that can generate a few Coffers.
With Mirror, you can gain additional Mountain Shrines for $3 each.
With Mirror, you can gain additional Overlords for $3 each. Opening double Overlord should be considered.
With Mirror, you can gain additional Royal Blacksmiths for $3 each.

With the cost of a Nearby Action card reduced to 0, it can be piled out with ease.
Tragic Heroes are likely to end up in the trash, at which point you can play them via Necromancer, gaining Treasures along the way (if you manage to increase handsize enough).
You can play Actions from the trash as Horses, leaving them there, turning Necromancer into a flexible Laboratory variant.

Playing Lich and Voyage on the same (main) turn cancel each other out. Just make sure you don't play Lich on your Voyage turns!
Horses are insane Procession targets. Whatever you do, using Paddock to stuff Horses and Processions into the deck as soon as possible is usually a winning move.
Rushing Page on t1 or t2 is a great way to quickly get them exchanged.
Don't miss out on the TFair/Page opening, especially powerful on the 4/3 or 5/2 as you'll get to exchange before shuffling.
Just don't be all too comfortable with those Palace points with Panic around...

By revealing your hand with Poor House, you can generate additional Coffers with Patrons in hand.

Adding one or two Patrons to your deck while going for a Rebuild strategy can help you generate a few Coffers along the way that might be useful to spike Province or Duchy towards the end of the game.
Revealing a hand of Patrons can generate additional Coffers when playing Royal Blacksmiths, which might incentivize you to go for Blacksmiths in games with Copper trashing.
Scrying Pool can draw Patrons while generating Coffers. However, you can also give your opponent Coffers.
Seers can draw Patrons while generating Coffers.
Making your opponent reveal a hand of Patrons might not have the desired effect. In games with Patron, this might disincentivize going for Taxman even more.
By revealing Patrons from your deck, you can generate additional Coffers.
With Way of the Chameleon, you can play Patrons as cheap flexible Laboratory variants.
By discarding Patrons with Witch's Hut, you can generate Coffers while Cursing the opponent.
Rushing Peasant on t1 or t2 is a great way to quickly get them exchanged.
Don't miss out on the TFair/Peasant opening, especially powerful on the 4/3 or 5/2 as you'll get to exchange before shuffling.
If you pull Insignia from the Loots pile, you can use it to topdeck Sirens without the need for trashing an Action.
Pulling Spell Scroll from the Loots can autopile Treasurers.
As long as the Tireless cards are Actions, them being on top of your deck provides reliable setup for Piazza hitting them. Of course this is a Nombo with Tireless Treasures.

Pulling Spell Scroll from the Loots can autopile Treasurers.
Playing the Cursed Gold with Debt on the Curse pile will give you that Debt.
With Watchtower in hand, you can trash the Curses you gain from playing Cursed Gold.
Remaking Coppers will gain you Poor Houses, which you usually don't want.
Upgrading Coppers will gain you Poor Houses, which you usually don't want.
With Way of the Chameleon, Poor Houses become +4 Cards, but may deplete any $ you have racked up so far if you have Treasures in hand.
With Possession, you can cause your opponent's Actions (even their Possession) as Way of the Horse, potentially crippling them until the end of the game.
With Woodworkers' Guild, you can trash an Action card into a Possession without having to gain a Potion.
Strong combo where thinning Estates and Practicing a bunch of Souks will get to ~7 Provinces in about 10 turns even without support.
You can Practice Tanuki from your deck, which is sometimes useful to trash even more quickly.
Practicing one Wine Merchant gives a net +$5 and is Buy-neutral (although you might only want to spend $3 of that to leave $2 to discard it).
Preparing a Night card such as Raider will prevent you from being able to play it during your Night phase, and at the start of your next turn, it will just be discarded.

Swamp Shacks benefits from having lots of cards in play, which you can sometimes achieve by preparing a bunch of stuff. Has the disadvantag of requiring +Buy to work, but in otherwise strong kingdoms without thinning this can be relevant.
Preparing a Night card such as Vampire will prevent you from being able to play it during your Night phase, and at the start of your next turn, it will just be discarded.
If you manage to set aside a Reckless Action, it will be played twice at the start of each of your turns, and never return to its pile.
Way of the Turtle can help immensely to set up a good collision of your Prince, and Princing an Action at the start of turn also has the benefit of immediately being able to play it.
Horses are insane Procession targets. Whatever you do, using Scrap to stuff Horses and Processions into the deck as soon as possible is usually a winning move.
Horses are insane Procession targets. Whatever you do, using Sleigh to stuff Horses and Processions into the deck as soon as possible is usually a winning move.
Horses are insane Procession targets. Whatever you do, using Stampede to stuff Horses and Processions into the deck as soon as possible is usually a winning move.
Horses are insane Procession targets. Whatever you do, using Supplies to stuff Horses and Processions into the deck as soon as possible is usually a winning move.

When Processing Actions, you can opt to play them as Way of the Turtle on one of their plays, which sets them aside for next turn, avoiding to be trashed, while still gaining that Action costing $1 more.
If you gain a Siren and topdeck it using Progress, you don't need to trash an Action card in order for the Siren to stay in your deck.
Once Progress is active, the set-aside card by Summon will be topdecked and not played at the start of the next turn.
If you pull Insignia from the Loots pile, you can use it to topdeck Sirens without the need for trashing an Action.
Pulling Spell Scroll from the Loots can autopile Treasurers.
Reducing the cost of Stonemason to 0 with Quarry allows to overpay for Actions easily.
Having two Quarries in play lets you autopile Villas while generating lots of extra Actions and a bit of $$.
Quartermaster is a great way to both gain Sheepdogs and trigger their Reaction.
With Sleigh in hand, you can immediately gain the card you would gain onto Quartermaster to your hand by discarding Sleigh.
With Tools, you can easily snatch Quartermasters once your opponent has put one in play.
With Watchtower in hand, you can immediately gain the card you would gain onto Quartermaster onto your deck.
If you gain a Siren and set it aside using Rapid Expansion, since it's set aside after being gained, it will stay there even if you fail to trash an Action.
The presence of Road Network should slightly disincentivize going for a Rebuild strategy.
With Scrounge, you can get Rebuilds into deck quickly, but it also heavily depends on your opponent leaving Estates in the trash for you.
Sometimes, Sewers can help you to trash out Coppers in order to find your Rebuilds more often, although it usually needs support.
Topdecking a card of your choice each time you are shuffling increases the strength of Rebuild significantly.
Transporting Rebuilds can help you getting a few copies in deck (even topdecked on demand) quickly, accelerating the depletion of the Province pile.
If Reckless is on an Action card, you can topdeck it with Scheme to prevent having to return it to the Supply.
If Walled Village is Reckless, you may topdeck it during Clean-up if you only have this and at most one other Action in play, circumventing Reckless' return-to-pile prompt.
Having a Samurai in play will give your Rice the Action, Duration and Attack type in play each turn.
Since you gain Curse first, when trashing Wayfarer with Ritual, it will cost 0, yielding no VP.
Having a Trail trashed from the top of your deck will allow you to draw a card.
Nice to draw in your buy phase after having played Treasures
Playing Ronins from your deck using Way of the Mule essentially turns them into flexible, reliable Peddlers (+1 Card, +1 Action, +1$) that are available whenever you shuffle.
Playing Ronins from your deck using Way of the Otter essentially turns them into flexible, reliable Smithies that are available whenever you shuffle.
Playing Ronins from your deck using Way of the Ox essentially turns them into flexible, reliable Villages that are available whenever you shuffle.
Playing Ronins from your deck using Way of the Pig essentially turns them into flexible, reliable Laboratories that are available whenever you shuffle.
If you gain a Siren and topdeck it using Royal Seal, you don't need to trash an Action card in order for it to stay in your deck.
By Rushing Shaman during the opening, you might be able to smuggle an Estate into your opponent's deck before they shuffle.
You can Rush Sirens for $5 without the need to trash an Action for the Siren gain - insanely strong (and swingy in the opening)
By Rushing Snake Witch with an empty hand, you are guaranteed to be able to Curse the opponent. Especially powerful in kingdoms with weak thinning.
If you pull Insignia from the Loots pile, you can use it to topdeck Sirens without the need for trashing an Action.
Pulling Spell Scroll from the Loots can autopile Treasurers.
If you gain a Siren and use Sailor to play the Siren, Siren no longer requires you to trash an Action card from your hand in order to not trash the Siren.
If there is cost reduction (e.g., Canal, Inventor, Bridge) around, playing Scepter on Sculptor to gain Scepters autopiles Scepters while generating Villagers.
Triggering a shuffle full of green and then topdecking Shepherds can feel great! Just watch out for those discard attacks.
With Woodworkers' Guild, you can trash an Action card into a Possession without having to gain a Potion.
Gaining Sheepdogs to hand allows you to immediately play them for draw.
With SP, you can set up reliable Sea Chart draws.
If you pull Insignia from the Loots pile, you can use it to topdeck Sirens without the need for trashing an Action.
Pulling Spell Scroll from the Loots can autopile Treasurers.
With Treasurer, you can regain Magic Lamps from the trash in order to gain more Wishes.
With SP, you can set up reliable Sentry trashes.
With SP, you can set up reliable WW draws.
With Shamans around, it's very likely you will gain a card from the trash at the start of your turn, triggering Sheepdogs for free.

With Shamans around, having a Watchtower in hand at the start of your turn allows you to directly trash the incoming junk. There is also a minor synergy with Shamans being able to reduce your handsize before drawing with Watchtower.
If you have an empty deck and multiple Vampires, you can use the immediately draw the Bat of the first Vamp play. Probably pretty niche to come up, but hey, it's there.
Reacting Sheepdogs with Way of the Monkey allows you to generate extra $ in your buy phase even if you otherwise didn't have the Actions to play them.
Reacting Sheepdogs with Way of the Pig around allows them to become Villages if you manage to gain cards during your Action phase.
Reacting Sheepdogs with Way of the Rat allows you to gain more Sheepdogs, and Ratting the first one allows to trigger Reaction for others.
Reacting Sheepdogs with Way of the Sheep allows you to generate extra $ in your buy phase even if you otherwise didn't have the Actions to play them.
Reacting Sheepdogs with Way of the Squirrel allows you to generate extra $ in your buy phase even if you otherwise didn't have the Actions to play them.
Triggering a shuffle full of green and then topdecking excess Shepherds via Frog can feel great! Just watch out for those discard attacks.
With Sleigh in hand, you can topdeck Sirens without the need for trashing an Action.
Having played a Tiara, you can topdeck Sirens without the need for trashing an Action.
Having played a Tracker, you can topdeck Sirens without the need for trashing an Action.
If you gain a Siren and topdeck it using Trapper's Lodge, you don't need to trash an Action card in order for it to stay in your deck.
If you gain a Siren and topdeck it using Travelling Fair, you don't need to trash an Action card in order for it to stay in your deck.
With Watchtower in hand, you can topdeck Sirens without the need for trashing an Action.
If you gain a Siren and topdeck it using Way of the Seal, you don't need to trash an Action card in order for it to stay in your deck.
If you pull Insignia from the Loots pile, you can use it to topdeck Sirens without the need for trashing an Action.
With Way of the Chameleon, Souks become +7 Cards, +1 Buy, but deplete any $ you have racked up so far.
With Watchtower in hand, you can immediately trash any Squires you gain and even topdeck the Attack card gained that way if you so want it.
Trashing and regaining Stockpiles with Treasurer can un-exile them even if the pile is empty, which is sometimes useful.
Buying Stockpiles, discarding copies from Exile, returning to your Action phase with a Villa buy, and redrawing them can generate a lot of money.
Playing Storeroom before Tactician allows you to get some value out of your Treasures and handsize in general. Just remember that you need to keep at least one card in hand to discard.
Summon gets around Swamp Hag's attack, which is great as long as you don't mind only picking up cards that cost $4 or less.
Having a Trail trashed from the top of your deck will allow you to draw a card, and gain you another $4-cost card.
Toil is a great way to play Tactician after having played your Treasures.
Playing Vault before Tactician allows you to get some value out of your Treasures and handsize in general. Just remember that you need to keep at least one card in hand to discard.
Playing Tanukis from your deck using Way of the Mule essentially turns them into flexible, reliable Peddlers (+1 Card, +1 Action, +1$) that are available whenever you shuffle.
Playing Tanukis from your deck using Way of the Otter essentially turns them into flexible, reliable Smithies that are available whenever you shuffle.
Playing Tanukis from your deck using Way of the Ox essentially turns them into flexible, reliable Villages that are available whenever you shuffle.
Playing Tanukis from your deck using Way of the Pig essentially turns them into flexible, reliable Laboratories that are available whenever you shuffle.
Having a Trail trashed from the top of your deck will allow you to draw a card.
Discarding a Trail with Way of the Mole allows you to play it either for its usual effects, or as another Mole, allowing you to draw 6 cards in total, and giving you an extra Action.
Setting aside Trails on-gain to play at the start of the next turn is a nice Village effect.
Pulling Spell Scroll from the Loots can autopile Treasurers.
With Woodworkers' Guild, you can trash an Action card into a Possession without having to gain a Potion.
Discarding a Village Green with Way of the Mole allows you to play it either for its usual effects, or as another Mole, allowing you to draw 6 cards in total, and giving you an extra Action.
Discarding a Weaver with Way of the Mole allows you to play it either for its usual effects, or as another Mole, allowing you to draw 6 cards in total, and giving you an extra Action.
You can play Werewolf as Way of the Turtle in your Night phase to set it aside for the next turn without needing to spend an Action.
Playing Conjurer as Way of the Turtle will make you unable to play it normally again (as Duration cards that leave play will cease to function on future turns).
